One easy way to actually derive the whole inverse matrix formula step-by-step is by creating an (n)×(2n) size matrix, then put arbitrary coefficients on the left side (columns 1-3), and then the identitiy matrix on the right side (columns 4-6), then row-reduce the whole thing until the left side has become the identity matrix. If you do that then the right side should become the inverse matrix of whatever was on the left side in the beginning, and from there you can also factor out the determinant from all those coefficients.

+Ruoyao Zhang He was correct. Cross out 2nd row and cross out the 3rd column.  Multiply 2 by 1, minus 3 times 1
+Fynx Factora It's because of his French accent I think. In French r is given a sort h-ish sound.

Laurelindo Except that you can only call them 'columns 1-3 and 4-6' when n=3.   But yeah, I think that way is easier, too, especially since there's not as much 'magic' involved as with the method in the video.

VVayVVard Yeah, I arbitrarily picked a 3×6 matrix because it was easier to make my point that way, when I had some concrete numbers. =P  It's fun to try and derive all the reasonings that formulas are based on, and it also gives you more intuitive understanding for them. As a rule, I think one should always try to figure out the steps that lead to a formula, at least if they aren't too complicated and time-consuming. This also reduces the need to look up formulas in handbooks and whatnot, since you will be able to derive them yourself.
I agree, it's much more meaningful than trying to memorize everything. :)
Linear Algebra is an undergraduate level course. It is the more advanced applications that are at the graduate level- nanophotonics, parallel computing, atmosphere and ocean forecasting, etc.
Thanks for answering my questions. I'm looking forward to see MIT's Open Course Ware for Linear algebra.

***** Sir, are you in the Math Department at MIT?  What about Functional Analysis, Banach Space, Hilbert Space, Spectral Theory, Non-associative Algebra, Topological Spaces, etc, as the higher level extensions of Linear Algebra??  And "Linear Algebra Done Right" (using Halmos or Axler  to review and expand basic Linear Algebra) is typically one of first graduate math classes.  I cannot imagine any of the courses you mentioned being in the Math Department.
sanjursan Have a look at this course list to see what we have listed for Linear Algebra: http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/find-by-topic/#cat=mathematics&subcat=linearalgebra

in order to do that they would have to start teaching geometry to sixth graders. The common advanced math student in sixth grade doesn't have the brain structures necessary to handle geometric proofs and logic at that age.   Calc two is plenty of preparation for higher mathematics, physics, engineering curriculum.

Even if you're 15 and learn multivariable calculus, most likely that 15 year old doesn't have the mathematical maturity to really have an insightful grasp of the concepts and question the lemmas within.  When you don't have mathematical maturity, you're merely memorizing the subject material.
Nathan Smith Well, depends on your interest really
@NathanSmith-ru8ic  as a 15 year old who´s currently doing AP Calc and has an A in it, what you´re saying is wrong

Really?  Did I say AP Calc?  I'm not trying to be rude or anything, but AP Calc does not teach you mathematical maturity.  Proofs are the foundation of mathematics.  Once you're in junior and senior level mathematics (university level), then you tend to gain a more mature mindset in maths.  I once was in AP Calc and I can tell you looking back that not a soul in that class had a clue what possibilities lie in upper level maths.

But to also save face, I also said, "...most likely..."  There are young people who are extraordinary and can grasp concepts and develop mathematical maturity at a young age.  Richard Feynman was a great example.
Nathan Smith extraordinary? There are like 20 people in the class who’re all really good at it. Maybe when you grew up things were different

You know there's much more math beyond calculus right? lmao  I'm 22 dude.  They didn't change the AP Calc curriculum much mate.  Just because someone is really good at math doesn't mean they have mathematical maturity.

However, I'm not going to argue with a high school student about mathematical maturity.  Just to put it in perspective, calculus involving both integration and differentiation up to 3 dimensions as well as differential equations are all considered "baby maths" in uni.  Please understand that when I say mathematical maturity, I mean being able to write definitive proofs with clarity in a mathematical research paper and develop unique and original mathematical ways to solve problems...not the ability memorize the methods to integrate and differentiate elementary or transcendental functions.
Also, don't cherry pick my arguments.

Nathan Smith yeah in ap calc there isn’t as much rigor as a proofs class but not many people need that. Most people taking ap calc are not interested in a career in math, but the sciences. I myself am learning multi variable calc to prepare for ap physics c. Physics being a subject I care much more about than math.
I agree with that.  Good luck to you.  Depending on what science you go into, though, you just may need proofs after all. lol.

Nathan Smith as a computer scientist I don’t really need the proofs that a mathematician uses. I for example have to prove the complexity of an algorithm using Turing machines, which is a math topic exclusively only taught in computer science classes. I do have to do some induction proofs as well but tbh they aren’t as rigorous as a math student does it. Tbh our exams are some what similar to an engineers exam, we are allowed tables that have integrals, derivatives, common logarithms, Fourier transforms etc and these are all included in a section in the exam, moreover we are also allowed a calculator.

MIT teachers give 1 class per semester and have TAs to do grade activities for then. These MIT teachers are not comparable to the regular teacher in a community college or smaller university who give multiple classes simultaneously and have to do grading thenselves.   In reality the primary job of an MIT teacher is to do research, you wont get tenure at MIT unless you have an h-index around 20 or higher, thats a very elite group composed only of world class researchers. You may find more pedagogical teachers in other schools who will never teach at an Ivy league school because they are not as impressive researchers as they are teachers.

@fateplus1 Recitation is when students meet up with an instructor outside of the lectures and watch the instructor work through problems in greater detail than is done in the lectures, in order to reinforce the concepts that are taught in the lectures.
